title: blind eye iran no longer option
story: No president could ignore the killing of US contractors, the invasion of its embassy in Baghdad, the threat to the lives of American service personnel.If that threat was imminent, he was right to act. We would have done the same to protect British servicemen and women. In fact, as Britain’s Defence Secretary I did exactly that, with the full support of Prime Minister David Cameron.Let’s not forget that every country has the right to self-defence.Of course, nobody wants this crisis to escalate. Indeed Iran’s retaliation has been noticeably limited so far.But the chorus for “de-escalation” carries risks too. Iran has been attacking Western shipping, including capturing a British tanker. Iran has fired missiles at Saudi oil refineries.Iran continues to wage proxy wars in Lebanon, Syria and Yemen. Through its militias, Iran continues to destabilise neighbouring Iraq.At some point, somebody had to draw the line. Qasem Soleimani was no hero or statesman. He directed terrorist attacks across the Middle East.Thousands of Syrians, Iraqis and Yemenis died as a result. Iranian dissidents, too, were brutally suppressed.The roadside bomb-making he sponsored killed many of our brave servicemen in Iraq. As Prime Minister Boris Johnson reminded us, he had the blood of our soldiers on his hands.Has Trump’s strike weakened the case for Western intervention  It is worth remembering our troops and those of the US are in Iraq at Iraq’s invitation.Since , we have helped lead an international coalition of more than  countries to support its fragile democracy and liberate that country from the terrorist death-cult of Daesh Isis.And thanks to precision strikes by the RAF and the training by the British Army of thousands of Iraqi troops, Daesh has lost the pernicious grip it once had.Defeating Daesh isn’t just a matter of helping a friend in need or of standing up for human rights. Mercully, we have stopped Yazidi women from being raped, prisoners being burnt alive, gay people being thrown off buildings and Western hostages sadistically executed.But tackling Daesh terrorism is also vital to protect our own way of le here in Western Europe.Islamist fundamentalism needs to be defeated, whether in Mosul, Raqqa, a Paris suburb or on London Bridge.So yes, let’s continue to work with our allies to persuade Iran’s revolutionaries to take a dferent path.Saudi Arabia, the other Gulf countries and even Russia all have roles to play in getting Iran back to the negotiating table.After the appalling shooting down of the Ukrainian airliner, let’s try to show the Iranian people their government needs to be more truthful and more open, that there is a better future beyond the mullahs and the republican guards.But diplomacy alone will not be enough. We have to protect our national interests too. Trump’s strike is a stark reminder that in the end, we must all stand up when those interests are threatened so directly.First, we must persuade other European navies to work with the US and our own Royal Navy in patrolling and protecting convoys through the Strait of Hormuz.This is a vital choke point for Europe’s trade and energy. The gas and oil we need this winter pass through it.It is ludicrous that some Nato allies won’t work with American ships for fear of upsetting the mullahs in Tehran.This has to be a US-led international operation.Second, we need a better nuclear agreement with Iran. It was right to try to halt their nuclear programme. But the previous deal wasn’t comprehensive — it didn’t even cover missiles — and it completely failed to constrain Iranian misbehaviour in the region. If anything, Iran used the access to new finance that deal released to step up its proxy wars in Yemen and where.A new deal should ensure full oversight of all Iran’s nuclear activities by the International Atomic Energy Agency, and only allow Iran back into the international markets when its civil nuclear programme is in complete compliance.Third, we have to step up our campaign against terrorism.Outside the EU after Brexit, we will still need to share intelligence and work together with our European partners to identy new attacks. But our closest ally in the battle to protect our values will always be the US. We may not always agree with Trump’s tactics but we shouldn’t ignore that he has finally cut through the illusion — Iran’s current regime is not our friend.Iran will certainly have learned a lesson from President Trump’s decisive action. But I hope we will do so too.Turning a blind eye to those who foster international terrorism is no longer an option for any of us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what you do after mistakes important
story: But in all honesty, what really matters is not so much what happened but how we respond.Take the young woman who was in court this week after drunkenly propositioning male passengers on a flight from Abu Dhabi to Manchester. She askedthey wanted to join her in the “mile-high club”, then attacked cabin crew who refused her more alcohol.Demi Burton tried to headbutt and kick six crew members and passengers who tried to restrain her before she was arrested when the plane landed.In court, the -year-old claimed she had been drinking because she has a fear of flying and said this behaviour is out of character, which may be true.Her defence lawyer Martin Callery said: “She is thoroughly ashamed of herself . . .  and utterly embarrassed at the way she behaved.”But that is certainly not the impression she conveyed outside court, where she gleefully flicked obscene hand gestures at photographers.No doubt she stopped smiling when she heard she had been sentenced to six months in prison. Personally, I’m not sure how effective prison is. But the problem with reckless behaviour is that you have to face the consequences.And I really hope for Demi, this is the moment she gets her le back on track. We all make mistakes. It’s what we do afterwards that defines us.It would be easy to assume that Demi is a hopeless case. But she is young enough to turn her le around, to work hard, do better and see this rock-bottom moment as a catalyst for change.And then something good will come from what is a very low moment in her le. We don’t have to look far for examples of people who have overcome lapses or mistakes before going on to succeed.Take Robert Downey Jr, who went from drug addict to one of Hollywood’s highest-paid actors. Or Elton John and Robbie Williams, both of whom have overcome major drug issues before enjoying renewed stardom, fatherhood and, more importantly, a good le.While it is not the same as a drunken mistake, anyone who has made it in business will have a good few failures under their belt — whether it is a dodgy commercial decision, plain bad luck or a company that has gone bust.It is not what happens to us in le but what we do next that counts. So I am guessing that, from her cell, Demi might be reflecting on what she might do dferently when she gets out. Andshe isn’t, she should be.Because it is the getting back on the horse that counts, evenit means resisting the urge to go back to bed to hide. No one is perfect. No one gets through le without messing up or things going wrong.Before success, you will get temporary defeat or total failure. The key to getting through it is resilience. And one of the best gts you can give a child is to encourage them not to give up.By the way, I speak here from experience. Like any businesswoman, I’ve made some mistakes and had my fair share of knocks.There are some that I have managed to turn to my advantage and others that I have had to chalk up to experience.The key thing is that I have learned from what went wrong, then moved on. That experience has allowed me to create a mini-manesto on how to fail how to respond to setbacks and failure, which I’ll share here now:Give yourself time to recover and reflect. Force yourself to take small steps to get back on the horse. Do not accept failure. See it as a step on the journey towards success.Remember that challenging and dficult moments are what help you grow bigger or better. Without them, you would stay the same.The only people who haven’t experienced setbacks are people who are too scared to try. So “failure” is often a sign of bravery. Hold your head up high at all times.Try your best and be proud to do so, eventhings don’t always work out the way you want them to. Remind yourself: “Where there is a will, there’s a way.” And as they say, the best thing about the future is it comes one day at a time.ANOTHER new year, another month of looking at photos of scantily clad people on beaches in sunnier climes and asking myselfI am the only person who is not on the beach.This is the time of year for massive bikini-body and holiday FOMO.But let us all take heart that it is also, oh joy, the time of year for elasticated waists hidden under chunky knitwear.Personally, I am more than happy to swap the beach for nothing to shave and no stomach to suck in. Bliss.I’M sure parents everywhere were shocked to read the story of the son who bullied his mother and stepfather so viciously he has been jailed for three years for his controlling and coercive behaviour.When Nicholas Hazell, , of County Durham, went back to live with Judith Ridley, , and her reverend husband Stephen, , after losing his job, he made their lives hell.Hazell, above, created a “horrendous atmosphere” at the family home and flew into a petulant ragehe didn’t get his own way, Durham Crown Court heard.Among his worst outbursts were when Hazell threw his mother into a chair and spat at her while holding a screwdriver to his stepfather’s throat. He also told them: “I am a master of bullying.”It sounds horric.I feel so sorry for his mum, who must be devastated that her little boy turned into a cruel bully as an adult.I dont do needles when it comes to my face.  Lasers, facials, peels . . .  sure. But needles are another story entirely.If you are willing to take the chance of injecting poison into your face, at the very least you want a predictable result. And in my experience, you don’t get it.Who wants eyebrows at the top of their head, lips that come into the room before you do, or a forehead that doesn’t move  Not me, that’s for sure. However . . .This week I read that not only is the gorgeous Abbey Clancy having micro-Botox injections, hyaluronic acid fillers and vitamins, she is doing it with TWENTY needles at once.Abbey, , is having something called an aquagold facial, so called because each needle is covered in -carat gold. The marketing blurb claims this treatment will reduce pores, blur out fine lines and leave your skin with a vibrant glow.Some might say this is a slippery slope to the stronger stuff but Abbey looks amazing.  So it has to be worth a try, don’t you think I HAD to laugh at the photos of the BBC newsreader whose dress, which had burst open minutes before going on air, was cobbled together from behind by quick-thinking colleagues.  Liz Beacon’s outfit was patched up with gaffer tape and bulldog clips.I used to believe what I saw on TV. But since filming The Apprentice, I know all too well that all is not necessarily what it seems.Two examples spring to mind. First, the countless times I have been filmed in the boardroom with a smart jacket on top and leggings or even pyjama bottoms and slippers under the boardroom table.Second, and worse, the time I somehow forgot to bring a bra on a day I was wearing a white blouse.Luckily, a kind crew member who is roughly the same size as me lent me hers.  And the show, as it always seems to do, went on.I WAS appalled to read about the private Islamic secondary school that has been “unlawfully segregating” boys and girls for all activities except weekly assemblies, according to a stinging Ofsted report.One of the teachers theretold pupils “university is not for females”, according to the report. Which begs the question of where, then, is the best place for females  The kitchen Inspectors who visited Birmingham’s Redstone Educational Academy in November last year also found male students were given privileges and treated more favourably than their female counterparts when it came to sports, school trips and work experience.That was something disputed by the headteacher.That’s not good enough. There can be no place for a school like this and it should be closed down.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keir starmer posh remainer leader
story: It was this “Posh Trot” Remainer who drove a bulldozer through Labour’s so-called Red Wall and cleared the path for Boris Johnson’s invasion of its northern heartlands.It was Starmer’s campaign for a chaotic second referendum that persuaded millions of working-class supporters to vote Tory for the first time and condemn Labour to the political wilderness.Not surprisingly, Starmer’s critics now wonder why this proven loser is in pole position to run their party.Some point the finger at Gordon Brown quietly rallying supporters to the cause.The ex-PM and his protegé have been close since Starmer’s controversial reign as Director of Public Prosecutions from  to .Starmer, despite his reputation for defending human rights, is not above sly ploys.There is nothing wrong with being wealthy — except among the Momentum voters he needs to seize Labour’s crown. Perhaps this explains why his Wikipedia entry has just been doctored to delete his status as a “millionaire”. Not me, guv, protests Starmer.He is also weirdly reluctant to declare where he stands on the political spectrum. Is he a Corbynite or a Blairite or a bit of both  “I don’t have the names of former leaders tattooed on my head,” snfs the man named at birth after the first leader of the Labour Party.This knight of the realm, who played violin at fee-paying Reigate Grammar School alongside Fatboy Slim, claims a humble background as the son of a toolmaker.“I know what it’s like,” he insists, asraised in a cardboard box.Well, I went to the same school when it was a “bog-standard” state grammar. My father was a journeyman upholsterer. It didn’t give me any special insights.Starmer boasts in his new campaign video about picket-line stints alongside down- trodden Wapping printworkers — against my boss, Rupert Murdoch, a hate figure on the Left.This chameleon politician was dubbed a “Sir” on the recommendation of Gordon Brown, a title he discourteously declines to use because it invites contempt among those with a vote.His citation was for “services to law and criminal justice”, after a five-year term as DPP.At about the same time he was parachuted into Parliament as MP for rock-solid Labour Holborn and St Pancras, in London.It is here that self-respecting Labour voters should pause and reflect.Many believe these political plums were reward for the longest, costliest and perhaps most spiteful criminal persecution in history — ordered by Sir Keir Starmer.His new leadership video slyly refers to this time, apparently to boost his scourge-of-capitalism image among the “comrades” — even though politics should play no part in a DPP’s decision-making. In a travesty of justice, he rammed two dozen innocent journalists through Old Bailey trials on trumped-up conspiracy charges — a medieval catch-all which even the Crown Prosecution Service admitted was “an extremely dficult and rarely visited area of the law”.The prosecuting counsel was given a flea in his ear for “chopping and changing”, the charges against the journalists.The trials ended with acquittals all round, an admission that “no crime may have been committed” and this rebuke from the Lord Chief Justice:“What concerns me is the freedom of the Press and the desire of officials to contain information.“We must ensure the Press is protected — we can’t use criminal sanctions to undermine their position.”The defendants were all journalists on The Sun or the News of the World — then seen by the Left as fair game.The trials followed The Sun’s decision to switch its support from Gordon Brown’s floundering regime to David Cameron’s Tories.Some believe the two were linked — but surely that’s just a conspiracy theory.What is absolutely clear to those who care about the issue is Starmer’s readiness to use his power to curb Press freedom.As citizens of totalitarian regimes rapidly learn to their cost, without a free Press there is no such thing as free speech.IT’S win-win for the Sussexes and losses all round for the House of Windsor.Meghan’s first kiss-and-tell will be a bestseller, with all the gossip on Randy Andy and those secret royal scandals.Harry’s right-on charities will be milked for millions.Once our revered Queen has departed, the monarchy will dwindle to a sideshow on the US celebrity circuit.Charles is too old to compete and William is too dull, despite Kate’s best efforts.Hero Harry will emerge as victor in this grotesque civil war. I predict he will live to regret it. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: queen must be firm harry meghan
story: So we hope that Meghan and Harry can come to a suitable arrangement with the rest of the royals.But what’s clear is the couple must not receive a penny from the state.British taxpayers fund the Royal Family to strengthen our nation’s soft power, and to support vital charities.If Meghan and Harry can’t be bothered with the legwork, then it goes without saying they must give up the whopping perks which come with it.As for security, claims that to stay safe the pair need cash from daddy just won’t wash. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are rich beyond the wildest dreams of almost everyone in the UK.They are more than capable of paying for a few bodyguards. Andthey find themselves struggling, they could always cut down on the private jets.The Queen, Charles and Wills must be firm: the Sussexes have made their bed. Now they’ve got to lie in it.A CIVILISED nation treats its veterans with respect.Which is why we were delighted when Boris Johnson won the election on a manesto promising to end witch hunt prosecutions against ageing former soldiers who served in Northern Ireland.But to get Stormont up and running, the Prime Minister has brokered a deal with Sinn Fein which risks opening up new probes into thousands of Troubles veterans. This would be morally indefensible and politically mad.Yes, a working government in Northern Ireland would be a good thing. But the safety and wellbeing of our elderly veterans is too big a price tag.And given Boris won the election by being a proud patriot, it makes political sense for him to stand by the armed forces through thick and thin.If the PM is to hold the hard-earned trust of new Conservative voters, he must never give way to those who would put our old soldiers in the dock.IT would be fair to assume that anyone injecting plastic into someone’s face should have some qualications to do so.But a strange loophole in the law means that though Botox is classied as a medicine in Britain, dermal fillers aren’t covered by any regulation.A staggering  per cent of facial fillers are performed by people with no medical training, often in unsanitary conditions — with devastating results.Which is why The Sun’s Fabulous brand is launching the Had Our Fill campaign, urging for a crackdown on unregulated cosmetic fillers, and raising awareness to help women make safer, more informed choices.We’ve had our fill of dodgy fillers. title: where storm brendan path now
story: The Met Office has warned there is more rain and wind to come. through Britain on Monday, the strongest gust of mph recorded in the western Isles.A second low-pressure front brought further strong gales to much of the country on Tuesday, ripping off the roof of title: meghan markle racism press bigotry
story: By “they” I mean the liberal-Left commentariat, the people who hate Brexit, hate ordinary people and have, for some reason, grown to love our departing royals, Prince Harry and Meghan.This past  hours they have closed ranks around the couple, who have announced they plan to keep their royal titlesbut leave behind their royal duties — like some woke version of the Queen’s Guard.They have chastised anyone outraged by the staggering entitlement shown by the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, who have essentially said they want the status but none of the responsibilities of monarchy.They insist the poor couple have been driven out by racism.British author Afua Hirsch, writing in the New York Times, decries the “racist treatment of Meghan” in the Press.She says it is hardly a surprise Meghan has walked away from a nation with a Prime Minister “whose track record includes overtly racist statements” and a “Brexit project linked to native nationalism”.Boris Johnson has no such track record and the only people linking Brexit to native nationalism are elitist, upper-crust Remainers like Hirsch.But no matter. Why let reality spoil the narrative These claims made about the “racist” treatment of Meghan at the hands of the British Press are incredibly thin.The same non-examples are recycled over and over again. You have probably seen them quoteda thousand times.There is that Daily Mail piece from , when Harry and Meghan were first dating, that said she was “ straight outta Compton”.At the time, Meghan’s mother Doria Ragland lived in nearby Crenshaw, LA.Hirsch says this was an attempt to link Meghan with “racialised forms of crime”, meaning gangs.That is one hell of a reach. The piece was clearly just playing on the dference in Harry and Meghan’s social backgrounds.If Harry had been dating a white, working-class woman from Manchester’s Moss Side, I dare say the Mail would have done something similarly silly.Another favourite is that weird throwaway line Boris Johnson’s sister Rachel wrote, in a laudatory piece on Meghan, about the mixed-race American actress bringing some “rich and exotic DNA” to the pale Windsor bloodline. That is more cringey than racist.Several pieces have cited a single phrase in a Sarah Vine column for the Mail — she said she had a “niggling worry” about the royal couple’s engagement photo — as a bigoted dog whistle. That is, quite frankly, mental.Such is the lack of actual examples of the Press being racist about Meghan.The only leg this argument has left to stand on is that the sheer volume of criticism sent Meghan’s way was disproportionate.Racism is the only explanation for it. It’s an argument based purely on unveriable speculation and imputing motives. It is also b*****ks.When the couple first got together, the coverage was gushing across the board.It was only when Meghan and Harry started on their ious virtue-signalling cru-sades — such as jetting around to lecture on climate change — that people’s backs went up.That the couple had already been beefing with the Press probably didn’t help either.In , way before Meghan became a figure in our culture wars, Harry issued a remarkable statement rebuking journalists for the “racial undertones” of their pieces.That these privileged royals, kept in the lap of luxury at taxpayers’ expense, began to develop a deep-seated victim complex only heightened the resentment towards them.Last year, Meghan told ITV public le was a “struggle” and she was shocked that “not many people have askedI’m OK”. Poor princess.This picture of privilege is who the liberal Left has spent the best part of three years defending.Even supposed republicans have — after a bit of anti-royal throat-clearing — defended Harry and Meghan to the hilt and helped con- struct this absurd narrative that they are the victims of establishment racism.This says far more about the prejudices of liberal-Left commentators than it does about the tabloid Press. They routinely suggest Meghan’s supposed mistreatment in Brexit Britain is no coincidence.They think Britain is a foul place full of foul people, brainwashed by foul news- papers to hate the wonderful Duchess of Sussex and the brilliant European Union.What the liberal elite’s Meghanmania shows us is that, for all their posturing against right-wingers, monarchy and the old aristocracy, they are title: scarlett moffatt wowcher mystery deal
story: The Im a Celeb winner posted on Instagram from Barcelona where she is fronting a campaign for the online discount firm.She said: New Year’s Resolutions: self love! Be more spontaneous! Travel more! If you’re wanting to spontaneously travel more - Book a mystery holiday for £ and you could end up in New York, Bali, Disneyland or even Barcelona like me! .Reality star Scarlett also posted loved-up snaps of her and cop boyfriend Scott Dobinson in Barcelona for their one-year anniversary.She captioned one: I still cant believe this trip is £. One of the many reasons I love @wowcher.But the mystery deal has been slammed by furious travellers claiming they were forced to shell out more than the advertised £ deal.Holidaymakers are put into a Lottery-style draw for holidays ranging from two to seven nights based on two people sharing.Destinations include New York, Dubai, Las Vegas, Bali, Thailand, Ibiza, Rome and Disneyland Paris but customers dont know where they are going until after they have booked.The deal includesflights and a hotel stay - but is based on departures from Stansted, Gatwick, Southend, Luton and Heathrow.This means some customers end up paying over the odds when they wish to change airports, flight times or add checked baggage to their trip.One Wowcher customer wrote: Or you could or you could end up having just spent £ on a trip to Dublin for  people for my daughters th birthday and be totally shafted and not get what we’ve paid for. Currently waiting for a manager to ring me from @wowcher but wouldn’t touch this company with a barge pole !!!The trips include flights and accommodation, and some are even all-inclusive.You have to buy at least two vouchers, at £ each, and then you go into a draw to win your destination.Everyone will get a holiday, but you just dont know where youre going until the draw happens.But customers who want to fly from an airport that isnt Stansted, Gatwick, Southend, Luton and Heathrow will have to pay extra.It also costs more to change flight times or dates.One user said: My friend did it for us. title: labour leadership rivals turn on keir starmer
story: Two of the five candidates have made it clear they are not looking for a moderate new leader to steady to ship after Jeremy Corbyns devastating defeat.Leadership candidate Lisa Nandy urged members of the Labour party not to go for the easy choice of a moderate candidate.She warned it was not the time to steady the ship or play it safe at her launch yesterday.I am obviously not a candidate that represented safety or stability. I dont look like the leaders that weve chosen in the past and I suspect I dont sound like them either she said.The MP for Wigan did not name Sir Keir but according to the i newspaper, backbencher MPs said her comments were a dig at the millionaire London MP.Remainer Jess Phillips also steered clear of giving Sir Keir any praise when asked about who she would like to be the next leaderit was not her, giving her backing to Ms Nandy.The former barrister faces criticism of being too metropolitan and middle class to be Labour leader.He claimed he had working class roots and said my background isnt what they think it is.Rebecca Long-Bailey, seen as the continuity Corbyn candidate, came second best on  followed by Ms Nandy on .Sir Keir steamrolled the other candidates, after receiving  nominations by fellow MPs and MEPs in the first round of the leadership contest.Both Ms Philips and Shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry only just secured enough nominations to get through to the second round, with  colleagues backing them.The candidates will now have to secure  nominations from almost  constituency Labour parties, or three from affiliated members - atleast two of which have to be trade unions.Sir Keir has already been given the support from the biggest trade union, Unison.Top corbynista and boss of Unite trade union Ken McCluskey has refused to give his support to any candidate yet, saying it will be announced next week.He denied claims from the BBC he had been impressed by Lisa Nandy and has been tipped to support Ms Long-Bailey.Lisa Nandy has been backed by GMB trade union.The candidates will take place in a series of hustings on January , and have until February  to secure enough nominations to get them over the line.The final ballot by Labour party members will open on February  and the winner will be announced April . Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: moneybox junction rat run closure
story: The cash hungry junction at New King’s Road and Bagley’s Lane in Fulham, West London raked in £. million in fines for the council in .In the month before the rat run at Harwood Terrace was closed to traffic on October, , last year, , fines were handed out - a total of £,.But in the month after the experimental closure, , penalties totalling £, were given - a month-by-month increase of , could see the council bring in more than £.million in  months.The projected figure is dependent upon drivers paying the £ fine within two weeks of being penalised.Local resident Rob McGibbon branded traffic lights turn red.Angry drivers claim the phasing of the traffic lights creates a trap for drivers unfamiliar with their timing.Drivers caught in the box when the lights change must pay a fine cars an hour were driving down the narrow residential road.Local MP, Greg Hands, has called on the council to reopen the Harwood Terrace to vehicles.A council spokesman stressed the closure is due to title: meghan markle not pitchforked off uk
story: It follows the fortunes, or rather, misfortunes, of Americans who fall in love with foreigners and have just over three months to get married or send them home.A massive leap of faith, it’s usually a matter of days — sometimes hours — before the clash of cultures, personalities, values and expectations make this the television gt that keeps on giving.Perhaps Meghan and Harry should sign up for season eight. For how much did they really know about each other before walking down the aisle Prince William apparently advised his more impetuous brother to wait so he could really get to know his American bride first, but Harry took umbrage and didn’t listen.Perhapshe had, he might have worked out in advance that an independent spirit joining such a restrictive institution wasn’t going to end well.Instead, they leapt before they looked and, with the “-month bride” having packed her bags already, have saddled the -year-old Queen with yet another constitutional crisis.Back in , I wrote a piece defending Meghan after she was criticised by old school friend Ninaki Priddy for being “calculated in the way she handled people and relationships” and a “curator of a beautul le”.But following the lavish baby shower, the jet-setting with A-listers and the swt jettisoning of inconveniently outspoken family members, the latter sentiment now rings true.And, of course, becoming a member of the most famous royal family in the world was the cherry on the top of that beautul le.But Meghan soon discovered it was nothing like the membership of her beloved Soho House.The rooms are draughty, the decor chintzy and, instead of reading the morning papers in your cashmere loungewear, you have to rise early, put on a frock and make your way to some rain-lashed outpost to open the new wing of a community centre where “live your best le” sentiments, however well-meaning, aren’t required.Here’s what is required as a member of the British Royal Family: Turn up on time, shake hands, smile, say little more than “have you come far ” Repeat.Not because the royals don’t have anything to say. They do, and air their views in private.But in public, their job is to shine a light on whatever project they’re visiting, not themselves. To show — via action, not virtue-signalling statements — a strong sense of duty.And inthey get to keep their ious mansions, hundreds of staff, personal bodyguards etc without any whf of civil unrest.That’s the deal.But those still in Meghan’s social circle glowingly describe her as organised, focused, and opinionated — very much an independent woman used to having her voice heard.As Prince Harry told courtiers just before their wedding: “What Meghan wants, Meghan gets.”An admirable quality when it comes to breaking through the glass ceiling of corporate le or securing the best table in the best restaurant, perhaps.But the monarchy is an institution steeped in hundreds of years of tradition, and Meghan — who claimed she “didn’t know much” about Harry when they first met — clearly thought she’d mould it to her way of thinking . . . then rapidly discovered that it ain’t for turning.Not that The Queen didn’t try very hard to accommodate the wants and needs of the newly anointed Duke and Duchess of Sussex.Contrary to royal tradition, they were permitted to keep the christening of baby Archie as a private affair and, despite there being a perfectly nice home at Kensington Palace they could have used, a publicly funded, £.million renovation of Frogmore Cottage was authorised.A “cottage” I might add, that used to be five homes but has now been knocked in to one because they managed to dodge the usual ban that prevents such moves because of the UK’s housing crisis.Shortly after, Prince Charles launched his blueprint to try to solve the dilemma faced by millions of young people struggling to find a home of their own. Oh the irony. And after all that, they now want to use it part-time as they flit back and forth across the Atlantic.Meghan is feeling disillusioned and homesick. We get it, and sympathise.But let’s not pretend, as some claim, that she’s been practically pitchforked off this island by racist bigots.This is not a racist country and, besides, the British public initially greeted her engagement and later marriage to Harry with unbridled joy.We love Harry. He’s a thoroughly decent person and deserves particular praise for the work he’s done with the Armed Forces, both while serving and afterwards.No, the disconnect has come from the fact that Meghan is still a Hollywood celebrity at heart and, consequently, never truly settled in her often boring and restrictive new role.She misses the relative freedom of her old le, not to mention her family and friends.Again, we get it. But was it really necessary to flee these shores asescaping for her le Clearly besotted with her, Harry faces the stark decision of giving her what she wants or losing her for ever. Or perhaps he’s genuinely sick of royal le and wants out too.If so, let’s wave goodbye and wish them luck.But. The have-cake-and-eat-it plan to stop being a “senior royal” and just dip in and out of duties that suit them simply isn’t going to work.SussexRoyal — which Harry and Meghan have registered as an official trademark for everything from “emotional support services” to clothing and magazines — is a title and privilege that comes with duties and conditions attached, not a brand, be it charitable or otherwise.The future of the monarchy depends on the goodwill, support and interest level of the public, and a recent survey showed that, while the majority have no issue with their decision to go, they were strongly against any continued taxpayer funding of their lavish lestyle.So— as early indicators go — The Queen allows Harry and Meghan to call the shots while keeping their royal titles, their taxpayer-funded security and an allowance from the Duchy of Cornwall, then one suspects this will be discussed by students for centuries to come as the turning point at which the British monarchy began its steady decline to irrelevance and, ultimately, abolition.MOVIE mega-star Will Smith popped in to the retirement party of a woman he last met  years ago.Anita Scipio was the receptionist at a US radio station when Will arrived for one of his first interviews as a young actor and he’s never forgotten how nice she was to him.“My favorite moments on the road are the ones where I can connect with people like @anitascipio,” -year-old Will told his Instagram followers before he walked in to the station to give her a hug.In the days before social media, someone who worked at his record company Sony told me that whenever he was in town, Will would tour the building, from post room to boardroom, giving time to everyone.He’s that rare creature, a star on screen and off.Some of today’s petulant slebs should watch and learn.FORMER psychiatric nurse Susan Evans is launching a landmark legal case to challenge consent issues around the provision of puberty blockers and cross-sex hormones for under-s.She argues that children should be protected from “experimental” and “invasive medical treatment”, not least because “some children are referred despite having autism, being homosexual or suffering some form of trauma or sexual abuse”.Speaking on Radio , she added that children as young as nine were being asked to consent “to a completely experimental treatment for which long-term consequences are not known”.But gender ersity advocates warn that “a loss to trans youth is a loss to all”.Time will tell the outcome of her case but, meanwhile, in unrelated comments, I note that the actor Rupert Everett says he spent most of his early childhood wanting “to be a girl”.He adored his mother, aunt and grandmother, didn’t like men, and adds: “I loved necklaces and bras and all those kinds of things.”Then, when he reached , he “didn’t want to be a girl any more. I really enjoyed being a homosexual”.The case in point, perhaps, for treading very carefully indeed with pre-teens.POLICE officers will be required to have degrees from this year – a move that could remove , recruits from the front line while they complete their studies.Sigh. Really When it comes to tackling crime on our streets, the majority of us want someone on our side who possesses instinct, courage and common sense.Which you either have or don’t regardless of qualications.NATURISTS John and Donna Price have moved from Kent to Lincolnshire for more privacy because they like to barbecue in the nude.“I love a flambeed banana,” says Donna, .Oooer.Aren’t our AEs under enough pressure Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun readers views harry meghan
story: Hundreds of YOU have ­written in with your thoughts, by email and on text.  Here we share some of your views on the Duke and Duchess of Sussex’s split from The Firm.HAVING grown up in the royal household, Prince Harry should know that the HRH title is not compatible with a part-time job.He should be given  days to decide whether he and his we want to keep the titles — with the perks such as taxpayer-funded security and the obligations like being seen at Sandringham at Christmas — or surrender them and have the freedom to do whatever they want.Jim Warren from BathI AM not a university educated person but I do know the meaning of “independence”. Having royal protection, receiving £million a year from the Duchy and having Frogmore ­Cottage at their disposal is not financial independence. Give taxpayers some credit. If you want to leave the UK, don’t expect us to keep you in comfort. Get a job.Peter Jackson from LeedsHARRY should have been given an ultimatum. How disappointing this has all been, when royals openly show that all they think about are themselves. All we have heard is about how Harry will have to pay tax and possibly £,-a-month rent for his “cottage”he leaves.Every low-paid person in this country has to pay tax and for a roof over their head. Why don’t they   If Harry wants to leave then he should be free to do so like anyone  on the understanding that all titles and payments will be forfeited.  It is to be admiredpeople want to stand on their own two feet.Wendy Lively from Hexham, NorthumberlandHOW right to call the Meghan and Harry crisis Megxit. Just like Brexit, it has outraged the nation. But how disappointing that the Queen has shown that selfish couple leniency It will beggar beliefthey are allowed to keep their titles and income yet refrain from royal duties.  What a shame the plain-speaking Prince Philip wasn’t allowed the final say. He’d have sent that arrogant pair on their way with their ears ringing.THERE is no reason why the Sussexes should not lead a more private le and step down — but not at the expense of the country. They should not keep their HRH titles as they have proved they are not royal. Did Meghan Markle join the Royal Family for prestige Mavis Sinfield from Whitstable, KentMEGHAN should be stripped of her title so she can make her way financially independently.  If they still want Frogmore Cottage, she and Harry should sign a lease and pay back the £.million the public paid to refurbish it. They have done more damage than any other royals in the last  years, so give them the obscurity they crave.C Duffy from Stoke-on-TrentTHE QUEEN has missed a golden opportunity to show us how strong she is. She has let Harry and Meghan off the hook and given the despicable couple what they want.I never had any time for royalty yet I did respect the Queen. She’s blown it big time. Workers are paying tax through the nose to pay scavengers Harry and Meghan.JK Bate from Bilston, West MidsShe has given her blessing so allow the couple to live their le as they please, just as you and I would like to. Respect our Queen’s decision.Jay Reeves, Caterham, SurreyPublic feeling now is very much that Meghan can’t have what Meghan wants. We appreciate Her Majesty’s “family” is involved but that family needs a public mandate to survive. Harry and Meghan have totally eroded that mandate.Chris Martin from Rochford, EssexIT seems to me the Queen has capitulated in the Meghan and Harry crisis because she had no choice. She either kicks them out of the Royal Family, which she would never do, or she compromises and we, the taxpayers, are left to pay the bill — albeit through the Duchy of Cornwall — to indulge the pair’s selfishness.Ken Pennington from Stalybridge, CheshireMAKING this announcement on Kate’s birthday, with the Duke of Edinburgh just out of hospital, and refusing to clear it with Prince Charles or the Queen first makes Harry and Meghan look terrically selfish.Marcus Walker from MiddlesboroughTHE Queen looks tired and sad. She doesn’t need this. Grow up, you two!Anon by textI’VE worked for  years. Anything I’ve wanted I’ve had to do overtime and save for. Can I have a refund of my share of Frogmore Cottage William Ensor from BirminghamI’M  and still have to pay tax on my pension just to keep the ignorant young royals happythey don’t want to earn their crust. Kick them out. Meghan has caused all this trouble with the Queen.Bryn from NorthantsTO give Harry and Meghan what they want we should stop all the money they get from the Government and The Duchy of Cornwall. If they get any money from these sources it will upset a lot of the Queen’s subjects.Dave Mashiter  from Exeter, DevonWHY didn’t Harry and Meghan mention these thoughts before a lavish wedding and £.million house ­renovation !Bea from CumbriaHARRY and Meghan won’t need money from the ­public purse. Fergie has made a fortune living off of her title.Terry Smith from Gillingham, KentHARRY touting Meghan’s voiceover skills is no better than Fergie touting meet-ups with Andrew several years ago to earn a few bob.  He and Meghan should renounce everything here — titles, homes and security — and go to Canada as ordinary citizens.They have enough contacts to make a good living on their own and should leave the hard-working royals to get on with the job that they do so well.Sue Sutherland from HullI AM disgusted at how Harry and Meghan are behaving towards their family. In my opinion it’s all about ego.  Meghan waltzed in here expecting to eclipse William and Kate in the public’s eyes but she badly misjudged the whole scenario. She is used to being the centre of attention and had her nose put out of joint as she soon realised she would always come second best, and that doesn’t suit her.I’m surprised Harry, who has been under scrutiny since birth, is turning against the media. He is obviously being led around by the nose.  Let them go to Canada, without any support from the British taxpayer. They are not wanted here.Jean Spurr, address withheldHOW dare “’woke” leftie liberals claim the Sussexes are being driven out by racism  It’s nonsense and a disgraceful slur on this country. Harry and Meghan were showered with love by the public and Press until they began to whine and Meghan, in particular, realis­ed royal le can be dull and constraining.Then, to add insult to injury, they failed to give the Queen any notice about stepping back as senior royals. This wonderful woman has devoted every waking minute to the service of this country for  years, and to treat her with such disrespect was beyond the pale. It’s an awfully sad state of affairs, for Harry in particular, but racism is not to blame.Neil Coppendale from Shoreham-by-Sea, West SussexWITH what happened to Diana, I understand Harry wanting to step away from the spotlight but I get the feeling Meghan calls the shots. Maybe the Hollywood princess didn’t like the work of a real royal.With their brand name, they will still have an easy le but with one prince gone, Harry has selfishly put a lot on William’s shoulders.Matthew Wilson from WolverhamptonIT was most disingenuous of Meghan Markle not to think that her le would be seismically changed when she married a Prince.It is obvious that she does not possess the required qualities of allegiance to the crown and should therefore renounce the title of HRH and revert to becoming known as simply Meghan Markle once more.  I sincerely hope Prince Harry will one day realise the hurt and damage they have caused to Her Majesty and their once adoring public.John Burton from Worksop, NottsALREADY it has come to light that Harry and Meghan actually intend to live in LA and not Canada at all. How many more lies have we been told  Yet more proof that what the controlling Meghan wants, she gets.Watch out, Harry. Once she gets all she wants you will be the next person cut out of her le.Eddie Derby by textHARRY is out of his depth and is being used. I predict that within five years he will be unceremoniously dumped by fame-chasing Meghan.Roger Stilgoe from BirminghamIF Harry wants to branch out, what’s the problem  It’s not like he has abdicated.Patrick from LoughboroughMEGHAN chose to marry into the most famous family on Earth then moans about wanting privacy.Stefan Badham from PortsmouthFor more than  years this country has been multi-racial, as Prince Harry will know from our history. For Meghan’s fans to play the race card when she’s only had a warm welcome since she arrived is just ridiculous.Whatever the future holds for them many will wish them well, hoping their time in Canada is not funded by the public.Jack Amer from NorfolkOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: american designer shoes cake
story: Chris, , carefully pipes fake buttercream and sticks tiny decorations on the £ to £ shoes in Florida.He even uses baking tools like piping bags, tips and acrylic mediums of dferent types to get the texture and the decoration that give the shoes a three dimensional aspect.Chris says, “I love cake and waffles so much that I put them on shoes.I really thought it would be a dferent idea to try for women’s heels. Who doesn’t love sweets ”Chris, , from Orlando in Florida, started making the dessert-inspired shoes in  - but has recently seen an explosion of interest from customers.He added: “The handmade shoes are only online and we have a few boutiques that sell our manufactured items.Our shoes can be customised and most of our orders are wedding orders and can be altered from top to bottom.”Chris says the idea of making the shoes came from his stint at college where he used to create sneakers for students and try to make the texture look realistic such as metal, wood, water and even skin.“I always enjoyed the challenge of making things seem like something they weren’t.“I started Shoe Bakery with the same idea in mind by taking desserts and using them as inspiration for women’s heels.I experimented for a while before getting started and I notice that this could work.“It was shared on Facebook, and grew so fast within a week and then we started to grow on Instagram very quickly from everyone sharing our pictures.”Looks like a cake walk.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ross clark huawei 5g network
story: This is a company that has brought us the technology of an iPhone but at a fraction of the cost.I am no protectionist and I don’t fear the Chinese.When it comes to selling us consumer goods, I am more than happy to welcome China’s companies into the country to compete with British, European or US-made products.But it is a very dferent matter when it comes to allowing a Chinese company to build Britain’s next- generation broadband network — with all the security issues that raises.Unbelievably, the Government is seriously considering doing just this.Yesterday, the Prime Minister — who is due to make a decision next month on whether to award Huawei a contract to build parts of Britain’s G network — indicated that he is inclined to give the company the nod.Critics, he said, needed to suggest which other company ought to be allowed to do the work.I am sorryI am a little ignorant on this point. While I have bought several mobile phones, I have never gone shopping for an entire telecoms network.But surely there must be other potential contractors. Don’t we have a telecoms industry of our own It doesn’t say much for the Government’s privatisation of BTit is not in the running for this sort of work.What about our own Vodafone, which I thought was one of the world leaders in mobile phone technology Evendepriving Huawei of the work meant we had to wait a little longer or pay a little extra to download a movie to our phones, that would surely be a reasonable price to pay for protecting national security.And national security policy really is at stake.Yesterday the US reaffirmed that allowing Huawei to build our G network — even parts of it which are deemed to be low- risk — would be “madness” and could compromise the willingness of the US to share vital intelligence with Britain in future.This didn’t come in one of Donald Trump’s notorious am tweets but from officials working for Matt Pottinger, the US deputy national security adviser, and Robert Blair, special representative for international telecommunications policy.That they took the trouble to visit London to warn of the dangers we could be getting ourselves into ought to be seen as a red flag on Huawei’s involvement in our G network.Surely, the importance of being able to share intelligence with our most important ally should rank above pure considerations of cost.Australia has already blocked the Chinese firm from its G network.Yet here, the head of MI Sir Andrew Parker said he had “no reason” to think Britain’s intelligence partnership with the US would sufferinvolvement from the Chinese firm was given the green light.But Defence Secretary Ben Wallace underlined at the weekend that the US administration has threatened to cut off some intelligenceBritain approves Huawei’s involvement in G.He said: “Those things will be taken into account when the Government collectively decides to make a decision on it.”Our own Government — as it has been doing since Theresa May’s day — insists that only parts of the G contract would be awarded to Huawei.It would not be allowed to work on security-critical areas.But that isn’t good enough. Such is the complexity of modern telecommunications networks that it would be impossible to be sure that systems installed in one part of the network were not enabling data to be obtained from another.Whoever designs and builds a telecommunications system gains the power to interfere with it, or even switch it off, should it feel inclined.Of course, with modern communications a huge amount of damage can be done from afar.Evenwe are confident our broadband network is secure now, we can’t be certain that would remain the case.A company which installs a telecommunications network will necessarily continue to be involved in maintaining and upgrading the network it had designed and installed.We have to be absolutely sure the network is not being used for some underhand purpose.Huawei denies that it is controlled by the Chinese state, and has threatened to sue commentators in France whom it alleges have made that claim.But the precise relationship between Huawei and the Chinese state is hardly the point.What is certain is that China is not a democracy and there is always going to be a security issue when it comes to involving its industrial giants in sensitive work here.We would not allow a Chinese company, say, to build fighter jets for the RAF or to construct our radar defence system.This kind of work is rightly the preserve of contractors on whom we can rely totally, even in times of international conflict.Such is the importance of telecommunications in military and civil defence that we now have to think of mobile networks in the same light.The Government has been warning for years that cyber warfare is the big coming threat.In  it published a Strategic Defence Review which defined cyber attack as a “Tier One” threat alongside terrorism.Last November, the US and Taiwanese held a joint exercise in fending off a major cyber attack on Taiwan.At the time the Taiwanese Cyber Security Agency said it was the subject of an astonishing million cyber attacks every month, half of which came from the Chinese mainland.So why, then, is our own Government even considering commissioning a Chinese company to install a telecommunications network Of course, Boris Johnson is right to make it clear he is not Donald Trump’s poodle.We don’t have to take notice of everything the Americans say, on defence, trade or anything .But when it comes to our closest ally warning us that it might not want to share intelligence with us in futurewe let a Chinese company build our G network, we very much do need to take notice.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP title: neglected pets saved charities
story: The three-year-old pup was nursed back to health, doubling her weight to st at an animal rescue centre in Northumberland. Like Tiggy, with help from similarly devoted charities, these ill-treated animals have all pulled through – with tails that end happily, you might say.THEN: The mastf was found by RSPCA officers in June  suffering from the skin condition mange, caused by a parasite bite. Scrum’s skin was tender and raw and needed extensive veterinary treatment, say his rescuers.NOW: Scrum has made an amazing recovery and is back to full health at the RSCPA’s Bristol Animal Rescue Centre. He is now looking for his forever home, soyou can offer him a loving environment, get in touch with bristolarc.org.uk.THEN: When Trooper was found on the streets in  his fur was so matted that he couldn’t walk, as one of his legs had become fused to his ear.  The Lhasa apso – a breed from Tibet – was taken in by the Dogs Trust Leeds rehoming centre, where wardens said he was the worst case of neglect they had seen in  years.NOW: After being sheared under general anaesthetic, Trooper proved to be a trouper and was completely healed and ready for a new start in just a few weeks. Now in a foster home in Halax, he enjoys several walks a day and loves playing in his new garden.THEN: Hunter the kitten was abandoned last March in a cat carrier with a sign that read: “Help me please”.  At just five months old, the pitul puss had deformed front legs, straggly fur and a completely bald tail and he was severely underweight and malnourished. Yet even during intensive-care treatment at Battersea Dogs  Cats Home, Hunter loved cuddles from his carers.NOW: After specialist medical treatment for his front legs, and with his majestic coat grown back, Hunter is fully back to health and has begun a happier chapter in his le after being adopted by a family.THEN: The Shetland pony was found by the RSPCA in Godalming, stuck in mud up to her stomach, gravely underweight and with no food or grass to graze on. Originally from Dorset, Tink was left alone in a field and kept separate from other ponies.NOW: Tink has since gained weight and is looking so fit that she was chosen to be in a Christmas RSPCA ad.  Her carers say Tink loves food so much that they have to be strict with her diet.  Patricia Spargo, of the RSPCA, added: “She constantly makes us all laugh as she is so expressive. You can just see what she is thinking all over her face.”THEN: Last February the frail West Highland terrier was found having lost most of his coat, and skin and ear infections had been left untreated by his then owners. The itchy fungal virus needed a vet’s attention but instead Archie had been left to suffer in pain.NOW: While at a Dogs Trust vet’s appointment Archie was spotted by Westie fan Anne-Marie, who was looking for a dog to join her family. He has now fully recovered from his problems, thanks to medical treatment and the devotion of his foster family.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu trade deal fishing rights
story: Eurocrats hardened their position on demanding continued access to our waters after Boris Johnson vowed not to extend the transition period beyond December .The EU said talks on fisheries will now have a “direct link” to thrashing out tarf and quota free trade on goods.Previously, the EU had stated access for its vessels would be secured “within the context of the overall economic partnership”.But Mr Johnson’s insistence the UK will quit the transition come what may at the end of this year has sparked concern in Brussels.Eurocrats believe only a “bare bones” trade deal on goods will be done by then and want to play hardball over fishing for maximum leverage.In a briefing to EU diplomats, Michel Barnier’s team said any deal on “reciprocal” access would be of “unprecedented scale and scope”.The pact would include agreements on quotas that European fishermen can land in our waters and a clause to protect their livelihoods.EU negotiators want to get it done by July  this year — the date by which the UK must say whether or not it plans to extend the transition.EU trade chief Phil Hogan has suggested fishing rights may be secured in a “trade-off” with the UK over market access for the City of London.Eurocrats argue access for EU boats cannot be separated from tarf-free terms for British fish products on EU markets.The PM has vowed to take back control of UK fishing waters when the transition period ends.Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen warned the PM he wont be able to “have his cake and eat it” in trade talks. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry meghan no justification 2 3m
story: There can be no justication for the young quitters still getting any of their annual £.million from the Duchy of Cornwall which Prince Charles controls.The Family seem to think of that vast £billion estate as their private fortune. But it has simply been inherited by the eldest son of the monarch since . If the Royals are abolished — because, say, public support dries up — the estate and its profits revert to the nation.It is the nation’s property, Charles merely its . So there must be complete transparency over how he spends the millions it makes, just as there is for the Sovereign Grant paid direct to the Royals by the Government.We’ll say this too. UK taxpayers are fed up enough . . . but spare a thought for the Canadians. Why should THEY fund the Sussexes’ security till the couple are good and ready to move to LA They made their bed. They can lie in it. And they’re rich enough already to pay their own bills.REMEMBER Remainers claiming Boris Johnson would be Trump’s poodle  How’s that prediction working out On Iran he has attacked the President for ditching the multinational nuclear deal without a replacement.On Huawei he is demanding to know America’s alternative, since they are so violently opposed to the Chinese giant building our G network. The Sun ­happens to agree Huawei is a risk, but at least Boris is speaking his mind.And the PM is at odds with Trump over America’s reluctance to extradite death crash driver Anne Sacoolas.He must not give up on that. Even the US public wants her to face the music. They recognise the simple injustice of letting her hide in the States, cocking a snook at victim Harry Dunn’s parents.Not for the first time, though, Boris is proving critics wrong.THE preening, entitled arrogance of ­former Speaker John Bercow was never better exposed than by him blowing £, of public money on a taxi ride.Citing wafer-thin security fears, he saved himself a long train journey by taking a cab from Westminster all the way to Nottingham to lecture unfortunate students.We take great pleasure in knowing that all of Bercow’s anti-democratic Remoaner tricks and verbose interjections were instantly negated by the Tories’ election win and the arrival of an infinitely superior successor.The Government must block any honour for him, especially the peerage he wants.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle letter dad thomas
story: The letter has now become the subject of a landmark lawsuit as Meghan Markle pursues legal action against the Mail on Sunday, claiming they unlawfully published the privately penned piece.The Duchess of Sussex, Meghan Markle is suing British newspaper Mail on Sunday for damages after it published a leaked letter she wrote to her father, Thomas Markle, after her May  wedding.The Duchess claims it was a misuse of her private information and breach of .In a statement, the Duke of Sussex said he and Meghan were forced to take action against relentless propaganda.Prince Harry said: I lost my mother and now I watch my we falling victim to the same powerful forces.She has pledged to give any damages from the case to charity.As a part of the legal disclosures process to follow, Meghan could now be forced to hand over private text messages, emails and phone records.It is likely the Duchess will also be called as a witnessthe case is not settled out of court.Thomas Markle is also preparing to take the stand and testy against his daughter in the bombshell case.It would be the first time Thomas and Meghan would come face-to-face since .The five-page handwritten letter was posted to Thomas by Meghan’s Los Angeles-based business manager.The Mail on Sunday filed its defence at the high court on Tuesday, arguing that the duchess and other royals “rely on publicity about themselves and their lives to maintain the privileged positions they hold” and that she could not “have a reasonable expectation of privacy that the contents of the letter were private and would remain so”.They said there is a “huge and legitimate public interest” in the private lives of the royals and would defend the case, which comes as the royal family struggles with the Duke and Duchess’ decision to “step back” from their roles as senior members.Meghan asked her dad Thomas Markle, , to stop his “painful attacks” on her new husband, Prince Harry.The Duchess of Sussex wrote: It is with a heavy heart that I write this, not understanding why you have chosen to take this path, turning a blind eye to the pain you’re causing.”In the letter published by Mail on Sunday, the Duchess went on to tell her “daddy” he broke her heart into a million pieces.She wrote that Thomas caused her “unwarranted pain” while also claiming that he never called her to say he wasn’t coming to her wedding.Thomas Markle, a retired Hollywood lighting director, revealed he decided to release parts of the letter after five “friends” of Meghan spoke anonymously about her relationship with him to US People magazine.The Mail on Sunday, however, claim that the intimate details of Meghan’s broken relationship with Thomas, revealed by the five “friends,” could only have come from the Duchess herself, not least because it presented events entirely from her perspective.They also accuse Meghan of scheming to use friends to pressure UK journalists into dropping stories about her.Thomas Markle has said he only decided to release the letter after being hurt by how it was characterised and claim that Meghan expected it to be made public.He told the Mail on Sunday, I have to defend myself. I only released parts of the letter because other parts were so painful. The letter didn’t seem loving to me. I found it hurtful.He added: “When I opened the letter I was hoping it was the olive branch I’d longed for.”“I was expecting something that would be a pathway to reconciliation. Instead it was deeply hurtful, I was so devastated I couldn’t show it to anyone – and I never would have, had it not been for the People magazine piece which meant I had to release portions to defend myself.”Thomas also disputed suggestions he had made no attempts to contact Meghan after the royal wedding, reportedly providing unanswered texts and receipt of an unanswered call to a number he had previously used to reach Harry and Meghan.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast news today storm brendan
story: Further weather warnings have been issued for later today and into the evening, with torrential rain and strong winds forecast across most of the UK.Heavy rain is expected in many parts - the worst of which is likely to be in southern England this morning.Travel across the UK has already been disrupted, with flights, trains and ferry services delayed or cancelled.The high winds forced airlines to ert flights scheduled to land at Gatwick Airport.Gatwick Airport said two Wizz Air flights, four easyJet services and one Norwegian Air flight were erted.One easyJet flight from Edinburgh was forced to land at Birmingham.In Wales, more than , properties were left without power after a tree fell onto a power line in Bontnewydd, Gwynedd.The strongest gust recorded during Storm Brendan was mph in South Uist in the Western Isles of Scotland, with winds of more than mph also recorded in Wales and the Isle Of Scilly.The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning for rain across the south coast.Met Office spokesman Oli Claydon said earlier: We are looking at gusts of mph to mph with exposed coasts and the tops of hills seeing mph and maybe even up to mph.With that theres also going to be some rain, making conditions quite unpleasant.Its certainly going to be unpleasant driving conditions and could lead to disruption across many travel networks. On Monday, more than  homes were blacked out after electricity failures near Falmouth and Truro in Cornwall as the winds began bringing trees down across cables.In the Western Isles, all schools in Uist and Barra were closed and all bus services on the islands were also cancelled. Several Caledonian MacBrayne ferry services were affected, with some services cancelled due to adverse weather and others disrupted.Northlink Ferries also told passengers there may be disruption on services to Orkney and Shetland.Although the rest of the week looks unsettled, conditions are set to be drier and brighter at the weekend.

title: landlord accused of shocking racism
story: Ebrima Mboob, originally from Gambia, West Africa, arranged over Facebook to view a double room to rent in central London from landlord Elina Vimbsone.Mr Mboob claims that once Ms Vimbsone realised where he was from, she back-peddled by declaring: “It’s only for European people”.The -year-old – studying performing arts at the University of the Arts London – said he “could not believe it” when his viewing was abruptly cancelled because of his ethnicity.He said: “I was completely shocked at the landlord’s response and I still am today.“Growing up in England, I’ve experienced all types of racism, but this was the first time that I’ve experienced something this absurd.“What makes it even more shocking is the fact she said ‘will be brilliantyou can make the time to come and view’, but soon changed her mind once she realised I was black.“I wasn’t expecting her to even ask me about my background as I didn’t think it was relevant and she even had the nerve to say it wasn’t racist.Mr Mboob added how the ordeal has left him feeling self-conscious when cooking African food in case other people have the same perception.“She even tried to play it down by saying how she has Nigerian friends and that all their houses smell like what they cook,” he concluded.“I’ve just moved in with new housemates and I’ve developed serious anxiety about cooking around them in case they hate the smell too.”Ms Vimbsone declined to comment when approached by The Sun Online.Under the Race Relations Act it is unlawful for a landlord to discriminate against a tenant on racial grounds.The Act defines racial grounds as including race, colour, nationality or ethnic or national origins.According to the Race Relations Act, there are four main types of racial discrimination: direct, indirect, victimisation and harassment.Direct racial discrimination takes place when you are able to show that you have been treated less favorably on racial grounds than others in a comparable situation.It occurs when:Refusing to rent or let a property based on race is unlawful as it breaches section  of the Equality Act .In , Fergus Wilson – Britain’s biggest buy-to-let landlord – banned ”coloured” people - because he said they make his properties smell of curry.Mr Wilson issued the directive in an email to lettings agents Evolution, who handled some of his hundreds of rental properties.The email, which was leaked to The Sun, listed his requirements for potential tenants.One said: “No coloured people because of the curry smell at the end of the tenancy.”Mr Wilson, , who was once reported to own up to , properties in Kent, said: “To be honest, we’re getting overloaded with coloured people.“It is a problem with certain types of coloured people - those who consume curry - it sticks to the carpet.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDelighted Debbie and Ste Hodge are finally quids in after buying a house for a pound and turning it into a £, asset. They put “blood, sweat and tears” into the two-bed dump, bought under a council regeneration scheme. Debbie and Ste were shaken when they first stepped through the door – armed with a £, schedule of works from Liverpool City Council to bring it up to scratch. The th century terraced house had been hit by fire and had crumbling walls, broken bricks and burnt joists. But the couple worked -, did most of the renovations themselves and in  months transformed it into a cosy home for just £,. After enjoying their first Christmas in the double-fronted home in the city’s Wavertree district, the pair have been buoyed by a valuation of £,. Debbie, , says: “We never want to move because we have put so much of ourselves into this house. People thought we were nuts. “We’ve crawled on the floors, we built the floors… it’s a gamble we took and we love it. Our blood and guts have gone into it. If they’d give us next door, we’d do it again!” Recalling the first time she saw the property, Debbie says: “It was just a shell. All the joists were burnt. It was terrible. “Honestly, it was just stacks and stacks of bricks. There was nothing. My family were saying to me, ‘You’re mad’.”  Every floor had to be replaced, chimneys were removed, the sinking kitchen was underpinned, all fittings were ripped out and the windows were upgraded. Debbie and Ste, , used their savings and took a small loan to complete the work – and it was hard graft. We were there until midnight with torches. We went seven days a week, we didn’t miss a day,” Debbie says. She scoured local ads for bargains and bagged a £, kitchen for a tenth of the price and a £, bathroom suite for £,. They also picked up a slightly damaged £, front door for £.  And, slowly but surely, the place came together. Now it is a shining example of how Liverpool is breathing new le into former slums. The council unveiled its Homes For A Pound scheme in . A year later, bosses vowed that , empty houses would be brought back into use. Since then, , homes have been reoccupied – including  in the Webster Triangle, Wavertree, where the Hodges live. Seven more families are due to move in soon. A similar scheme has since been launched in Stoke-on-Trent. Last year, a Channel  documentary about the renovations in Liverpool featured Debbie and Ste.  The couple say the sense of community in the Webster Triangle is a great example of how councils candepressed areas to homely neighbourhoods. The Hodges used to rent in Anfield and had struggled to get a mortgage. Debbie suffered a serious long-term illness and Ste’s wages as a carpet cleaner were not enough to secure a home loan. Debbie says: “The council scheme was the best thing to happen to us. It brings communities together. When we moved in, there were only about three houses in the road occupied. But it’s moving on now, it’s coming to be more of a community and about half the street is filled.  “We’ve met all the neighbours and introduced ourselves. People come from everywhere, dferent areas, dferent countries. It’s a lovely community and I’m really settled here. I just love it. Once a month we clean the street and make it nice. The area is coming up, there are bars and restaurants opening further down the road… I just wouldn’t move. “I can definitely see the area getting better and we’ve never been so happy.” The couple have two daughters – Jade, , a psychologist who has her own home, and -year-old teaching assistant Jenna, who still lives with her parents and is studying for an MSC. Debbie hopes the Homes For A Pound scheme will help young Liverpudlians like Jenna get on the property ladder.

title: darren lewis harry  meghan
story: NewsopinionDarren Lewis: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are right to put themselves firstThey are young people who want to go their own way, says Mirror Columnist Darren Lewis, millions of families have themShareCommentsByDarren Lewis:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsopinion" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIf they want out, howled the critics, they should give up the taxpayer cash and their positions in the Royal Family. Fair enough, said Harry and Meghan, we will. Cue the eruption. The critics want to have their cake and eat it. As in any dysal situation, they dismiss anything from the Sussexes unless it falls into line with whatever they want. Harry – forced to walk through London behind his mother’s coffin as a -year-old – can’t open up on his mental health issues without being attacked as weak. Meghan can’t breathe without being vilied for showing a lack of consideration to the Queen, the Crown, the flag and the Empire. The Sussexes are not allowed to set their own boundaries. Not when “duty” demands they are there to be pushed around.Of course, race has played a part in it. That much is obvious to large sections of black and white Britain. Yes, Camilla, Diana and Sarah Ferguson were also treated badly, but not like this. Not with the sustained vitriol that Meghan has had to endure. From her son being mocked up as a chimp to criticising her for editing Vogue – even though Prince Harry edited Radio ’s Today programme and Kate edited the Huffington Post website. Social media critics claimed bi-racial Meghan was not pure enough to marry into the Firm. The inference has always been that she doesn’t belong. She has been derided as a a, intent on wrecking the Royal Family. The so-called “constitutional crisis” is Harry and Meghan fighting back.  They are young people who want to go their own way. Millions of families have them. Kids who decide they want no part of the way things have been done in the past, children of rock stars who aren’t interested in music, footballers’ kids who don’t like sport. Frankly, the Sussexes are right to put themselves and their own wellbeing first. Of course, Home Secretary Priti Patel can’t see the problem. She serves under a Prime Minister whose overt racism is well documented. This debate, however, could yet become a turning point for our media. Most of the royal commentators stamping their feet over this are white. Most of the newsrooms covering this are largely white. The real time backlash is from black Britons with a digital  who are determined to have their say.  Angry, polarised race-baiting for social media hits is not the answer. The solution is a better ethnic mix in our media to give us an understanding of how to address this issue. Royal Author Penny Junor was left stumped on CBS This Morning when she vehemently insisted race was not a factor in Meghan’s treatment. “Did you check in with any black Britons before you made that determination ” asked the presenter. Junor was left stuttering. It appeared she hadn’t. All Meghan has done is back her husband as he chooses to move out of his grandmother’s house and fend for himself.
